newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy Juventus not seeking bourse listing - magazine.
newsitem.headline: Italy Juventus not seeking bourse listing - magazine.

text.p: Italian soccer club Juventus has no immediate intention of seeking a stock market listing, the club's honorary president Umberto Agnelli said in an interview with weekly magazine Panorama.
The Turin-based European Cup holders are currently leading Italy's Serie A. Recently, industrial group Fiat transferred its 42 percent holding in Juventus to the Agnelli family holding company IFI.
"Juventus does not intend to seek this (listing) on the bourse. At the moment, there are no conditions for such an outcome," Agnelli said in the magazine interview.
He added that to obtain a listing on the stock market, a soccer club has to show a strong balance sheet and preferably a profit.

A number of Italian soccer clubs, such as AC Milan and Bologna, have said they intend to seek a stock market listing. Italian media have suggested they might seek a listing in London where a company does not need to show a profit history before flotation.

Another top Italian soccer club, Parma, was more cautious. Calisto Tanzi, whose family controls Parma, said in an another interview in the same magazine that such a decision would require more consideration.
